newsitem.title: JAPAN: Crudes mostly range-bound in Asia, wet market slow.
newsitem.headline: Crudes mostly range-bound in Asia, wet market slow.

text.p: Crude oil prices moved within a narrow range in Asia on Thursday with trading in the physical market dull due to a lack of firm buying interest, market participants said.
June cash Brent was notionally assessed at $18.10/18.20 per barrel in late afternoon Tokyo trading.
On SIMEX, June Brent was last traded at $18.10 and was indicated at $18.11/18.15.
In the physical market there were vague rumours of deals done for June barrels of Oman and Lower Zakum.
A European major was believed to have sold a June Lower Zakum, while South Korea was rumoured to have purchased a June Oman but details of the deals were unavailable.
June barrels of Qatari crudes are believed to have all found homes, traders said.
Some European majors are believed to hold a few more June Abu Dhabi cargoes, but the light gradea are failing to attract much interest from potential buyers, traders said.
Some traders blamed the lack of interest on high domestic stocks of oil products such as kerosene and gas oil.
Moreover, China appears to have made large purchases of West African crudes sapping its appetite for Middle East and regional grades, traders said.
In the Asian crudes, traders said a 150,000-barrel May Minas had been sold by a Japanese trader to China earlier this month at a premium of 18 cents to the official selling price.
China was also believed to have bought 600,000-barrels of May Tapis at daily market assessments plus 40 cents, traders said.
